If I do not obtain the goods, I will never leave this place.
Again, it is said:
The best food is eaten first, the middling food is eaten in the middle, and the inferior food is eaten last.

As for obtaining alms from others, one obtains alms from others, does not speak ill, avoids places where one obtains bad food, does not cling to places where one obtains bad food, and does not go frequently to beg, seeking everywhere.
Again, it is said:
Evil cannot destroy their intentions, and good does not give rise to attachment.

As for why is this liberation, thus without remainder, the wise skillfully speak of purity.
Hunger and thirst are the first illness, action is the first suffering,
To know this as it truly is, nirvana is the highest bliss.
As for hunger and thirst being the greatest illness, it has been explained in the section on cutting off the hand and bestowing the prediction.
Cutting off the hand is not as painful as hunger and thirst.
As for action being the greatest suffering, there are various kinds of action.
If one knows this as it truly is, nirvana is the highest bliss. One who can know such action, without accomplishing the action of speech, will then have bliss.
Furthermore, it is said:
As for hunger and thirst being the greatest illness, one is always bound by it, even to the point of being incurable.
As for action being the greatest suffering, knowing it as it truly is, one can know these various actions.
As for nirvana being the highest bliss of all actions, cessation is bliss, non-observation is bliss, eternal bliss.
Furthermore, it is said:
As for hunger and thirst being the greatest illness, this is the truth of suffering.
As for action being the greatest suffering, it is the action conditioned by ignorance.ğŸ”½...
To undergo various afflictions is called the truth of accumulation.
To truly know in this way is the truth of the path.
Nirvana is the supreme bliss, which is the truth of cessation.
The robe of shame and conscience is the brahmin's, the brahmin's hands are pure,
The water always flows without stopping, the tongue is the cleansing device.
As for the robe of shame and conscience is the brahmin's, it has already been explained in the prediction of the Venerable MahÄmaudgalyÄyana.
Just as clothing is used to cover and conceal private parts, so too is shame and conscience, covering and concealing private parts.
As for the brahmin's hands are pure, it is just like having already purified the fire sacrifice, so too do I cultivate pure conduct, leaving behind unwholesome actions.
As for the water always flows without stopping, the tongue is the cleansing device, it is just like using a cleansing device to wash an impure vessel.
So too is my tongue, removing defiled conduct day and night without rest.
The fire sacrifice has a constant conception, relying on the inner mind and thoughts,
Diligent in sacrificing day and night, without losing the precepts.
For those who always think of sacrificing to fire, stop and contemplate the burning of the wisdom fire.
Relying on the inner mind and intention, oneself relies on the mind and is able to extinguish.
Practicing the precepts day and night, without losing the faculties, within oneself is able to contemplate the mind and receive instruction, this is called concealment.
Furthermore, it is said:
The hidden places are body, speech, and mind.
The precepts and training are the complete fulfillment of all precepts.
Furthermore, it is said:
The robe of shame and austerity is the arising of good conduct.
The pure water in the hands of the brahmin is always flowing and not staying.
The tongue is the basin for washing, the tongue is good conduct.
The second verse refers to the good conduct of the mind.
Among the three good conducts, it is called the brahmin.
Always reprimanding those who lack shame, I and even more so you must,
Also do not engage in wrongdoing, know that this is not me.
Those who are ashamed are those who should be ashamed but are not.
They should know that they do not associate with themselves, let alone associate with others.
Those who always scold others are not close, and one should know that they dwell in their own place with resentment.
What I tell you is that all defilements, although carefully followed by sentient beings, should be known as deceitful and defiled.
Also, those who do not engage in wrongdoing, all those who are intimate and friendly do not give rise to vexation, and the skillful means they employ should be known as carefully avoiding enemies.
Not being free from desires, thoughts are also insatiable,
Contemplating those who are able to be free from them, they are endowed with sufficient wisdom.
As for not being free from desires, it has been explained in the Bodhisattva's Predictions.
Up to thoughts and desires being also insatiable, one is unable to go and be free from those attachments.

Those who are able to be free from them exhaust the thoughts and desires of the present, and in the middle, contemplating the time of their exhaustion, this is said to be those who are able to be free from them.
They are fully endowed with wisdom refers to those who contemplate the impurity of desire, yet are attached to craving.
Seeing well in each truth - the Venerable One praises the gods.
Seeing well in each truth - truth refers to the truth of suffering, the truth of the origin of suffering, the supreme truth is the truth of the path, and the truth of cessation.
There is another explanation:
There are three truths: the truth of suffering, the truth of the origin of suffering, and the truth of the path. The supreme truth is the truth of cessation.
There is another explanation:
Truth refers to the truth of equality, and the supreme truth is the ultimate truth.
Liberated from this and that bondage, liberation is seen again as bondage -
The sages do not see liberation, liberation is from delusion and confusion.
This has already been explained in the chapter on the prediction for the only son.
Liberated from this and that bondage means liberated from false speech, yet tainted by killing.
Liberation is seen again as bondage means liberated from one harm, yet tainted by another.

The sages cannot escape this. Seeing the truth, one attains liberation from delusion, but one cannot attain liberation from bondage and fetters. Thus, one attains liberation from the view of annihilation.
Bound by the view of eternalism, one attains liberation in this way through hearing and contemplation.
Thus, one attains liberation from the view of self. One is bound by the fetters of grasping at doubt.
Attaining liberation from greed, one is bound by the craving for form.
Attaining liberation from the craving for form, one is bound by the craving for the formless.
Regarding long and short, coarse and fine, good and evil conduct,
Not taking what is not given in the world, thus is called a brahmin.
Regarding long and short, the answer is:
Long and short are not accomplished.
If there is little to observe there is long, if there is little to observe there is short.
This is the TathÄgata's admonishment.
Moreover, the coarse is also not accomplished.
Question:
How is the measure also not accomplished?
Answer:
In this, it is not said that the measure cannot be upheld, nor is there any coming.
If one does not accept taking what is not given, then that is coarse and also not accomplished. In that, there is also no measure, there is pure conduct, and there is also a little accomplishment.
Question:
Those who have accomplished pure conduct.
Answer:
It is not by means of conduct that one takes what is not given, in that, pure and impure conduct are accomplished, that is the extensive tongue's admonitory speech.
Therefore it is said, The brahmin is one who is fully endowed with various practices.
Some say:
Arising of the fetters of taking what is not given, the exhaustion of the fetters is a brahmin.
The unwholesome yet has the wholesome, one should rely on the family of the three Buddhas,
Not dwelling in benefiting sentient beings, that is said to be relying on existence.
As for the unwholesome yet having the wholesome, within the unwholesome one finally gives rise to another place.
That one first extinguishes the original thought, and again obtains another thought.
Always relying on the family of the three Buddhas means not relying on the mother's womb.
Not dwelling to benefit sentient beings means passing away in another's home and growing up in the mother's womb.
They say while relying on existence, meaning that existence is wholesome practice.
If one often in the world changes, there is no victory, let alone in the world,
Forever extinguished without smoke or haze, in that one delights in non-harming.

The different entrances are external, the non-different are internal.
Furthermore, it is said:
The different are the gods, the non-different are the hells.
Furthermore, it is said:
The different are associated with the form and formless realms, the non-different are associated with the desire realm.
This counting is impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self. It is the self-characteristics and universal characteristics of cause and effect.
There is no victory, let alone in the world means ignorance sees what is to be known, as it is said to be attached to and bound by Mara.
Breath means the cessation of the three fires, the eternal cessation of the extinguished, the eternal cessation of smoke and haze, and the exhaustion of the afflictions of anger and hatred.
Furthermore, it is said:
The exhaustion of internal bonds and afflictions is like the smoke and haze of craving.
The breath with perception is also without smoke and haze, like the smoke of perception.
Harmless means the exhaustion of the three harms.
Hopeful means the exhaustion of the hopes for gain and life.
Furthermore, it means the exhaustion of craving and the ability to transcend.
Liberation and falling again, attachment and returning,
Having returned to the blissful place, abiding well in the good place.

Liberation and falling again means that one who is liberated from the desire realm is also liberated from the bonds and afflictions of the desire realm, but the craving for the form and formless realms is not yet exhausted. One falls into them and is reborn there.

Those who are attached and come back means those who are unable to completely eliminate the fetters associated with the desire realm, they dwell there, become attached to the methods there, are unable to uproot the defilements of the desire realm, and give rise to the defilements of the desire realm, coming back to the desire realm.
Having returned to the place of joy means the Buddha's Å›rÄvakas have returned to the place of peace, free from the troubles of birth, sickness, and death.
The place of joy refers to the eightfold noble path.
Dwelling well in the good, enjoying the bliss of samÄdhi, and roaming within it, forever returning to the blissful place is further explained as follows:
Those who are liberated but fall again means those who have attained liberation as a stream-enterer but fall into hell, they fall into the heavens and become attached, coming back again.
The craving of the desire realm is not yet exhausted, so they come back to the human realm.
Returning to the place of joy means being free from fear and the worry of entering hell.
Happiness refers to the path of the sages. For those who abide well in goodness, they transcend all bonds and return to nirvana.
It is also said:
Those who fall again and again are those with the view of annihilation. Liberation falls into the view of eternalism.
Those who are attached and come back again are those in the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.
In the views of eternalism and annihilation, they practice the path of liberation.
The rest are also like this.
